body.p:
Yours of last week was received, and I was truly ? to
hear of your being well. I myself also continue as usual,
and attend punctually to my work, which is progressing, though
not quite as fast this week as the last, owing to various distrac-
tions, among which chiefly the launch of the Pennsylvania,
which drove all hands away, and so was the cause of loss of
time. To be sure a day or so in general is not much, but at pre-
sent every hour unnecessary wasted is of importance.—I fear
I shall have to go again to New York at the completion of the
second volume, as the persons who promised to send the dues
on have failed to do so, and I do not know any one altogether
well calculated to do collecting in the manner it should be.
There are now ready or nearly so,

then before, and I will try my best to do justice to the undertaking.
I have paid already on account, up to Feb 7st. 15 printers 540, Paper
maker 285.75 = 825.75; ? then printers 95, Paper Makers 95. -/&2
Binder 68. = 1084.50, besides my expenses to New York and other little
things about 60 Dollars more at a rough guess; so that I have paid
already an amount considerably exceeding $1100.__I had a letter from
Jamaica this week. My other books, of which I sent 28 copies, here
been all taken and the nett proceeds after paying freight, ? and commission

were similar. The Books brought @ 4 doler? per copy and one bound @ 125
113.25, and I Ma?ed 95.72%; so that the expenses or so small amount
is almost eighteen Dollars. Of course I made the people there pay the
difference; but still the statement given proves how unpleasant
a thing it is to send books like mine to a place where either a person must lose one fifth or charge more than the regular price.
To be sure it is the same with every kind of good, yet people
mind it more when my stock in trade comes into play than upon
any other occasion._ _I should be glad to hear from Mrs Cohen,
that she had succeeding in obtaining orders for me. You may state
to Mr. E. P. Cohen that the number of copies now on hand is about
150 copies. Several are ordered, about 6 copies, some will be sent for to
D. C. and perhaps other places, though I have some doubts, if therefore
they should be required in England, it would please me to send
them out as soon as possible, in order to have them circula-
ting whilst I have yet enough left to supply all that may be
called for._

With regard to my election, Mr. Lyons has not yet ans'rd,
and his father knows not where he may be here. There is
but little talk, that I hear of, just now on the subject, and as
congregation meets in about 10 weeks it is just as well to let
the whole matter rest. As I said before, if an opposition is talked of
many may go to the meeting, that otherwise would and they do
so, there is no man in America that could be elected over me;
but if the knowledge of such a thing does not induce them to ? of their
own accord I would consider it beneath my dignity of which you
know I seldom speak, to solicit them to walk across the room,
Besides I doubt the policy of my ? any one. I have hitherto been

elected by a free choice, and it will hardly do for me to accept as
a favour after 8 years service, what was formerly given here as a
reward and to please themselves than out of favour to me. I
must take care not to lose the ground, one so very advantageous
with respect to an independent discharge of my duties, which I have
hitherto occupied, and if necessary it would be better to lose the office
than to obtain it upon term alluded to. There is however no
danger that I can see of any being turned out. Probably they
will reelect me for one or two years, as they never will take
me up as Hazan without specific and that a short period. The
most they will do is to say three, four or five years; beyond this
however they will not trust me or any one else, on principle as
they call it, assuming that they will not elect a person, whom
it will be requisite perhaps one day to turn out for incompetence.
it is therefore my settled opinion, that altho' I have always declared
that I would resign if a majority of the congregation desire it,
they will put my sincerity to the test, and keep the power
in their own hands.__

Mr. Joseph Moss has not yet paid me, nor said any thing
about his obligations and I will ? remind him of it for a considerable
time to come, perhaps never. If he settles his business well
he no doubt will pay and if he does not, my asking him will do
no good.—

The paper will give you a whole tail? 'bout the ?
the 74 on R?. It was a beautiful sight, altho' I was full a
mile off.
My best respects to aunt and all the family and believe me

whole are sold and all dues collected will leave me profit $512; I count then
chickens, which are not yet hatched nevertheless, the whole on hand will
not be a total loss, nor will all the debt remain unpaid; so that altho'
I went to very great expense with the books I shall not to say the
least be a loser thereby. I wish I could know the same of the prayerbook,
yet even here I have good reasons to be satisfied.— I. L.
